message.content:
<<<api>>>: javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilder, org.w3c.dom.Document, org.w3c.dom.Element, org.w3c.dom.NodeList
<<<code>>>: 
DocumentBuilderFactory factory = DocumentBuilderFactory.newInstance();
DocumentBuilder builder = factory.newDocumentBuilder();
Document document = builder.parse(new InputSource(new StringReader(xmlString)));

// Add node
Element player = document.createElement("player");
player.setAttribute("name", "Frank");
document.getElementsByTagName("players").item(0).appendChild(player);

// Remove node
NodeList players = document.getElementsByTagName("player");
for (int i = 0; i < players.getLength(); i++) {
    Element player = (Element) players.item(i);
    if (player.getAttribute("name").equals("Delete Me")) {
        player.getParentNode().removeChild(player);
    }
}

// Add attribute
Element team = (Element) document.getElementsByTagName("team").item(0);
team.setAttribute("city", "New York");

// Remove attribute
team.removeAttribute("deleteMeAttribute");

// Modify attribute
players = document.getElementsByTagName("player");
for (int i = 0; i < players.getLength(); i++) {
    Element player = (Element) players.item(i);
    if (player.getAttribute("name").equals("Michael")) {
        player.setAttribute("name", "Mike");
    }
}

// Set node value
players = document.getElementsByTagName("player");
for (int i = 0; i < players.getLength(); i++) {
    Element player = (Element) players.item(i);
    if (player.getAttribute("name").equals("Mike")) {
        player.setTextContent("node value for Mike");
    }
}

// Convert document back to string
TransformerFactory tf = TransformerFactory.newInstance();
Transformer transformer = tf.newTransformer();
StringWriter writer = new StringWriter();
transformer.transform(new DOMSource(document), new StreamResult(writer));
String output = writer.getBuffer().toString();
<<<explanation>>>: The Java API javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilder and org.w3c.dom.Document can be used to parse an XML string into a Document object, which can then be manipulated using the org.w3c.dom.Element and org.w3c.dom.NodeList classes. The Document object can then be converted back into a string using the javax.xml.transform.Transformer class.
